meanings.definition: Convert (data or information) into digital form.
meanings.sent1: I will digitise all the old photos so we can store them on the computer.
meanings.sent2: It is important to digitise important documents to keep them safe and easily accessible.
meanings.sent3: I tried to digitise my cat's meows, but all I got was static!
meanings.sent4: Her smile was so bright, it seemed to digitise the room with happiness.
meanings.sent5: The artist's goal was to digitise emotions through his abstract paintings.

meanings.sent1: We need to digitise the survey results to analyze them more effectively.
meanings.sent2: Scientists often digitise complex data to better understand patterns and trends.
meanings.sent3: I tried to digitise my feelings for pizza, but numbers just don't capture the deliciousness!
meanings.sent4: Her laughter seemed to digitise the joy in the room, making everyone smile.
meanings.sent5: The clock seemed to digitise time, ticking away the seconds with precision.

meanings.definition: To make (something) available in a digital format.
meanings.sent1: The library decided to digitise their book collection for online access.
meanings.sent2: Art galleries often digitise paintings to create virtual exhibitions for everyone to enjoy.
meanings.sent3: I tried to digitise my wardrobe, but my clothes refused to turn into pixels!
meanings.sent4: His words seemed to digitise the air, spreading his message far and wide.
meanings.sent5: The company's goal was to digitise their services, making them accessible to a wider audience.
